column1: Title: State Data and Policy Actions to Address Coronavirus | KFF

column2: Waive Cost Sharing for COVID-19 Treatment
column4: State Requires Waiver of Prior Authorization Requirements*

column2: State Requires (3); State-Insurer Agreement (3); No Action (45)
column3: State Requires (9); State-Insurer Agreement (1); No Action (41)
column4: For COVID-19 Testing (5); For COVID-19 Testing and Treatment (6); No Action (40)
column6: Grace Period Extended for All Policies (4); Grace Period Extended for COVID-19 Diagnosis/Impacts Only (4); Expired (8); No Action (35)

column1: For purposes of this table, states were included if they required insurers to take the listed actions. A number of states released guidance or recommendations for insurers to take the actions listed in this table but fell short of issuing a requirement and are thus not included.

* The Families First Coronavirus Response Act requires all group health plans and individual health insurance policies to cover testing and associated visits related to the diagnosis of COVID-19 with no cost sharing and prohibits them from imposing prior authorization requirements on these services during the federally declared emergency period. Federal law supersedes any state requirements.
See [here](https://www.kff.org/other/state-indicator/paid-family-and-sick-leave/) for more detailed information on paid sick leave policies.
1. Both DC and NM are requiring insurers to waive cost-sharing for treatment of non-COVID respiratory illnesses such as pneumonia and influenza.
2. DC's special enrollment period was not adopted in response to coronavirus, but is open to a broad group of people, including those who are uninsured.

3. While NY has not explicitly waived prior authorization requirements for COVID-19 treatment, the state has directed insurers to suspend prior authorization for all outpatient services delivered at hospitals, which could include services related to COVID-19.

4. OK requires a premium nonpayment grace period extension for all health insurance policies and prohibits insurers from canceling coverage for anyone diagnosed with COVID-19 and unable to return to work or maintain coverage due to COVID-19.
